jobs.title: Paid Social Work Intern (Summer Position)
details: As an MSW Summer Intern at Elgin Counselling, I have been engaging with clients for individual, family, and relationship counselling on a regular basis. I currently have a caseload of approximately fifteen regular clients, however, I occasionally see one time walk in clients. The clients I see are dealing with issues ranging from anxiety and depression, to traumatic bereavement and grief, to trauma and PTSD, to couples counselling and family conflict resolutions, to life skills management and development. I've also been assisting with the development and facilitation of a children's Mindfulness group as necessary and appropriate, in both St. Thomas and Aylmer. It is my responsibility to complete all necessary clinical documentation related to client contact. I have also been completing intakes and addressing client concerns over the telephone on an as needed basis.

The project involved developing a curriculum for a program to teach grade seven boys sex and healthy relationships education (SRE). I was also able to sit on the Sex Worker’s Action Network (SWAN) committee. I was also able to obtain some experience doing pregnancy options support counselling.

jobs.title: Office Administration, Case Management and Research Assistant

details: Details: The Sociology Undergraduate Student Association, in cooperation with The Sociology Department and the Qualitative Research & Resource Centre Falling In Love With Research Project provides students in Sociology with the opportunity to explore the process of planning, conducting and reporting research results using a variety of qualitative and quantitative methods. Surveys, focus groups and structured interviews were conducted on student's presentation of self on social media over the course of the school year. data

analysis and presentation of results. As Chair of FLR, my responsibilities included acting as a liaison between the research team and the SUSA executive team, budgeting, event and workshop planning, and seeing to administrative matters. I was also involved in the research aspect of the project, acting as a focus group moderator, survey designer, and qualitative and quantitative
data
analyst.

jobs.title: Support Line Operator and Educational Outreach
jobs.company: Sexual Assault Survivors' Support Line - York University
details: Details: SASSL exists to provide unbiased and non-judgmental peer support and referrals to survivors of sexual violence. The Centre provides a 24-hour support line during the fall-winter semesters of the school year. In addition to these services, volunteers are expected to participate in educational outreach programs and information sessions at the university and in the surrounding area. As a volunteer, I was trained to take crisis calls through several mandatory training days that emphasized a survivor-centric, anti-oppressive, and intersectional feminist approach. I spent approximately 3-4 hours per week answering the crisis line during school hours. It was expected that volunteers take home SASSL’s 24-hour crisis cellphone at least five times per month. We also worked with one of the Centre’s coordinators to participate in outreach programs at least once a month, delivering educational workshops on sexual violence to high school, organizations, and on campus.

jobs.title: Online Learning Community Facilitator
details: Details: YU START is a new student transition program designed to support students as they make their way from high school to their first year at York University. Through this summer long program, they enrol in courses, connect with fellow classmates and student leaders, and become more familiar with campus life, supports and resources available to them. Incoming students were assigned to groups of twenty-five in an Online Learning Community (OLC), two of which I responsible for facilitating. Each week was themed in order to educate new students about campus services and resources. The discussion about these topics was informal, with the intention of alleviating anxiety that students may feel when asking questions. Participating in this group allowed these students to make meaningful connections with their senior leaders and incoming peers within their program of study and affiliated college. This program required me to have flexible hours (5-10/week) and to actively initiate new topics of conversation, answer questions, and monitor comments while maintaining a safe and respectful environment. I was responsible for accurate provision of information regarding institutions, programs, and resources.

jobs.title: PSW/DSW
details: Before beginning my undergraduate degree, I applied for a job posting that I found on the Internet for a personal support worker in a private home that required little to no experience. The family required relief and support 2-3 days a week for their adopted son who had had been diagnosed with concurrent fetal alcohol syndrome (F.A.S.), bipolar disorder, learning/developmental disabilities, reactive attachment disorder (R.A.D.), as well as having a variety of conduct and behavioural problems. for real non Gaussian noise. When the known solution was only hypothetical, it was mistakenly assumed to be pure Gaussian noise, though everybody understood that it was a mistake about noise distribution and this mistake led to unrealistic results. However, the problem of dealing with real noise is so big, that no knowledge currently exists about how to handle it. I developed a theoretical foundation for how to use robust statistics theory to design statistical inference to solve this problem. I also developed a method for the theoretical probabilistic analysis of conventional methods and suggested new methods as well. Simulated stochastic behavior by Matlab.

jobs.title: SENIOR TECHNOLOGIST & LABORATORY SPECIALIST
details: Hallmarks of Contributions & Responsibilities:

❖ Process Improvement: Developed equipment management manual to establish new SOPs behind the calibration, validation, scheduling, and specifications used in the manufacturing process to provide a background and base-knowledge for new and current employees on how to properly handle equipment. Maintained, updated, and secured SOP manual and files.

❖ Identified Training Deficiencies: Distributed an online survey to grasp staff familiarity with the company's Learning Management System (LMS) that is designed to train them on their daily duties in manufacturing and quality control. Identified key deficiencies in the LMS by determining that the system was unable to verify if new and existing employees followed the training documents within to ensure each step in their methods was in line with SOP and the Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) guidelines.

❖ Direct Training of New Hires: Would provide training mentorship to onboard new employees, guiding them through the training matrix, training material, and assigning them a "buddy" that took them through ISO-governed steps on production and manufacturing.

❖ Workflow Presentations: Created a flowchart for assay manufacturing process that accounts for a specific demand in IVD kits based on sales figures by planning for the necessary raw materials needed and the amount of time a specific manufacturing procedure will take to produce a master mix. Specific points along the manufacturing process are designated for quality assurance testing before moving ahead with production.
Hallmarks of Contributions & Responsibilities ):
❖ Product Expertise: Provide a bridge between senior management and manufacturing team members to help identify potential process gaps in the production of IVD products.

❖ Customer Complaints & CAPA Investigations: Implemented necessary changes to manufacturing procedures identified via Corrective and Preventative Actions (CAPA) investigations to help mitigate mounting customer and client concerns over a specific aspect of the products.

❖ Instructional Manual Creation: Authored and revised process guidelines and manuals through Agile software resulting in a 50% increase in efficiency as a result of streamlined operational methods, coaching techniques on how to properly utilize the manual to increase production, and identifying common mistakes and avoiding them in future manufacturing.

❖ Laboratory Testing: Adhered to strict and methodical procedures while working through the Batch Production Records (BPRs) to build products according to specific requirements and governmental regulations.

❖ Hiring of New Staff: Followed a detailed employing procedure by conducting resume reviews and asking a self-generated set of interview questions to find the best candidate among the available applicants.
ADDITIONAL PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE

details: Responsibilities
PROJECT COORDINATION EXPERIENCE
•	Identified and promoted information and resource sharing between and among teams

data
for written reports, presentation and scientific publication purposes

and conducted statistical analysis
•	Prepared a written report, delivered presentations to stakeholders, offered recommendations for improvement
•	Managed the day to day operation of an enhanced Containment Level 2 laboratory, including training personnel, supervising technicians, purchasing supplies and equipment
RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
	Diagnostic assay development for virus and bacteria (molecular diagnostics)
•	Successfully developed new, as well as improved previous RT-PCR-based methods used by the Canadian Mobile Laboratory for field diagnostics during outbreak investigations
•	Designed, executed, and optimized every step of Real Time PCR Assay development for Ebola Cote d’Ivoire (new assay) and all other filoviruses (previous assays) testing

•	Performed molecular diagnostics to test for Marburg virus, Vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV), recombinant VSV-Ebola and VSV-Marburg virus, Shigella, Salmonella typhi, Vibrio cholerae, Yellow fever virus, malaria
•	Developed a multiplex molecular diagnostic assay for MRSA and mupirocin resistant staphylococci
•	Performed laboratory screening and detection of various Viruses using PCR and serological assay (immunoflorescence assay, immunoblotting, ELISA)
	Vaccine development (molecular biology and virology)
•	Development and evaluation of an optimized Adenovirus Ebola-based vaccine

-	Improved the antigenic expression cassette of Ad-CMVZGP through codon optimization, inclusion of a consensus Kozak sequence and reconfiguration of a CAG promoter (Ad-CAGoptZGP) for better expression in mammalian cells
-	Expressed the optmized codon of CAGoptZGP in Adhu5 by transfecting HEK 293 cells
-	Purified adenovirus Ebola-based vaccine using cesium chloride for mice vaccination
-	Performed ELISA to assay for induction of Ebola virus-specific antibody
•	HIV vaccine development using Ebola virus glycoprotein
-	Cloned Ebola virus glycoprotein in pCDNA3.1 vector and expressed it in lentiviral pNL4.1 vector for a DNA vaccine against HIV infection
-	Constructed various recombinant pNL4.1 vectors by deletions and site-directed mutagenesis
	Leading Investigational studies

•	Molecular investigation of signal transduction pathways that regulate cellular responses to Vesicular Stomatitis Virus (VSV) and two recombinant VSV (VSV-Ebola and VSV-Marburg virus) expressing the Ebola and Marburg virus glycoprotein instead of the VSV glycoprotein
-	Investigated the Ras and ERK_1/2 signalling pathway in Ras-transformed cell lines
-	Performed Immunoflorescence assay (IFA) and used fluorescence microscopy

In University I climbed with Bill Marsh who was the leader of the First Successful Canadian Mount Everest Expedition

At Sensor Geophysical I processed 2D seismic, land and marine transition, using GLI, PROMAX and MASTT.  MASTT is very useful for most surface consistent static situations, however I also used Promax’s correlation and maxpower for statics on

with low fold or poor signal. I have had a lot of exposure to complex foothills regions, and severe static areas.  Some areas include Mackenzie Delta, and Beaufort Sea land-marine transition zone, all which have ice problems.  Also the Norman Wells area, which has mountains, muskeg and the Mackenzie River flood plain.

At Affinity Geophysics I processed 2D seismic using GMG and PROMAX.  I had set it up so that I could link into work from home using Exceed for an xterm through the Internet on Shaw Cable.  I also reset the system to process from floating datum instead of fixed datum.
At C&C Systems in Calgary I processed 2D and 3D

on PC-SEIS processing software, from demux to final migrated stack.  I have also been involved in setting up an Internet connection using PPTP, setting up E-mail, made my own Web Page and installed and configured Exceed software to allow for an X-term connection to a UNIX system with Windows NT.

At C&C in Calgary I learned to use Kernel Technologies WinPICS 2D & 3D interpretation software, including grid balancing in just one weekend. I basically could process seismic and do an interpretation all on a Laptop computer. Also I learned to use the NT version of Paradigm (Photon’s) SeisX workstation. I helped clients to load
, made maps, and gave them support.
My work experience at C&C Systems includes:  1) projects from the Ukraine with very steep topography and high structure; 2) high structured
near Savanna creek south of Longview;  3) high structured

in the areas of Liard and Maxhamish; 4) New Zealand field Q.C. and full processing of 170 square kilometer 3D for one and a half months (this area varied between low to high structure);  and 5) field processing and Q.C. in Trinidad for 3 months.  My duties in Trinidad included processing 2D high structured
with complex velocities to migrated stack. After stack the

was sent to Calgary via Internet or Federal Express so the interpreter could get immediate feedback on the results and quality of the program.  I also set up a demo for the partners in Trinidad and did a presentation for the industry and government. They were very impressed with the cutting edge technology at that time.
I also did a demo in Venezuela in Caracas for the 3 major oil companies at the time. As well as one in Maturin Venezuela.

While in Trinidad, I helped redesign the seismic program as there where now houses where some of the 2D lines where supposed to go. We experimented with array width, and maximized cdp fold near the end of the lines affected by house development. Also used different dynamite with a higher frequency response in a sandy zone which greatly improved signal in the shallow horizons, as well as vertically stacked some areas both to increase signal and to mix low and high frequency source response, the results surprised and impressed the consortium partners very much.

Through Pulsonic, working in Damascus was a very challenging opportunity.  It required a great deal of flexibility and innovation as I had to adapt to a large array of unexpected circumstances, both technically and socially.  The people were very friendly and eager to learn, however it took some patience in overcoming the language barrier in order to supervise effectively.  This included adjusting to different business customs.  The working environment was adequate, however it was necessary to prepare for power surges and disruptions, as well as improvising due to a general lack of modern office supplies and equipment.  I organized training on the IndeX system and taught users general geophysical concepts.  I tested current and new software versions, reported to Calgary on software and system problems, and handled system maintenance and software support.  I processed and taught 2D and 3D seismic processing from different areas of Syria for the Syrian Petroleum Company.
At Columbia Gas I managed a GECO Charisma II Interactive Workstation. My duties included loading seismic and survey

, picking horizons, helping other users, managing their projects, plotting maps and archiving the projects. To add to this I had three months practical experience interpreting in the Peace River Arch area of Alberta.  Here I also became familiar with using instantaneous phase, frequency and amplitude attributes to help in stratigraphic interpretation, as well as AVO studies and use of well logs.

CGG & Dome Petroleum Ltd. I worked very closely with clients including geologists, geophysicists, and the applications research group.  This helped in developing a better final product and helped in my understanding of geophysics through a team effort.  My exposure to the applications group increased my knowledge of synthetic modeling and the use of well logs, as well as wavelet estimation, match filters and minimum phase equivalent wavelet extraction.  Also I used offset limited gathers for AVO studies and velocity field modeling for time to depth conversion.

summary: I have a broad range of experience in analyzing
and bioinformatics (more than 8 years). Recently, I was a
scientist intern at Visier, a prestigious company in Vancouver.

jobs.title: Data Science Intern
details: Visier is a company analyzing HR
data

to give a solution to the HR problems of customers. For each customer, Visier’s patented analytics technology looks back over previous months, at all employees and potentially hundreds of employee attributes, as well as the groupings within each attribute, and determines how much each correlates to the employee resignations that have occurred during that period. Visier then automatically assigns each current employee an "at risk" score, essentially ranking each employee from highest to lowest in resignation risk. Rather than focusing on who will leave, the focus in Visier is about why they are leaving.

During my internship at Visier I was working on improving accuracy of predicting employee resignation. In this regard, three subprojects were defined that two of them were about feature engineering, i.e. creating new features based on original features.

At first glance, they seemed easy, however, considering the restriction of "being explainable to the user" it turned out they are very challenging. While I was supposed to use wise methods to create new informative features, at the same time I needed to make sure that the new features are explainable to the user. The difference between these two projects was about the type of knowledge that we extracted from the original
data
. In the first one, we considered sense of time and sought for patterns of changes in the
data
, and in the second one, we captured the relation between employees in a group.
The third subproject that I worked on was about cross-validation procedure that aims to accurately estimate performance of the predictive model on unseen
data
. In this project, I customized the cross-validation procedure considering nature of Visier's HR
data
to make sure that the performance of the predictive model is not underestimated or overestimated in the tuning phase.

summary: Raphael is a recent graduate of the Master of Public Policy and Global Affairs at the University of British Columbia (UBC), where he specialized in natural resources governance, environmental economics,
analytics and climate change mitigation policies.
Multilingual and inquisitive, Raphael is a dedicated sustainability leader,
communicator and ocean steward. He has developed high proficiency in economic analysis, strategic policy design, environmental-risk assessments, climate finance and quantitative research methods.

Acutely engaged in the recognition of natural capital and intergenerational equity, Raphael manoeuvered through the complex inter-linkages between our economy and the environment, which led him to seek out innovative methods to appropriately value ecosystem services and foregone externalities.

Having served as a climate finance & forest conservation consultant for the "Tropical Landscapes Finance Facility" (TLFF) during his capstone experience in 2016/2017, Raphael had the opportunity to engage with a broad array of stakeholders and gain first-hand experience in Indonesia. He recently finished his year-long research assistantship in fisheries economics, promoting the concept of a "blue economy" while rising public awareness on sustainable ocean management. Currently enrolled in a
for Social Good Summer Fellowship, Raphael has been facilitating and encouraging
-driven decision making in the realm of tourism in British Columbia; applying innovative
analytics techniques that can then be replicated and extrapolated by his government client.
Raphael is a naturally optimistic individual who is personally convinced that today's young leaders could be the new catalysts of a substantial paradigm shift in the near future.

additional: Many factors impact store sales. For example, geography, weather, seasonality, promotions. In this project, I use time series analysis to predict store sales. As well, I make recommendations for future project improvements.
•	Dataset: Dataset contains sales and promotion details, along with competitor information of over 3000 drug stores in Germany with over 1.2 million observations
analysis, time series analysis (pyramid ARIMA and Facebook Prophet)
•	Best prediction: Mean Absolute Percentage Error (mape) = 0.04

This was a fun project where I used different ML methods to predict the binary outcome of whether a pet at an animal shelter would be adopted. Essentially this is a classification problem and can be thought of as a more interesting way for churn/not churn.
•	Machine Learning: Logistic Regression, Gradient Boosting Tree, Ensemble, and XGBoost
•	Best Prediction: A combination of Gradient Boosting and Logistic Regression provided the best model with a ROC_AUC score of 0.91

This is another fun project where I built an interactive app that will display detailed demographic information (e.g., age, income, education, primary spoken language) about specific areas in Toronto, Mississauga, and Scarborough.
•	Dataset: Master dataset retrieved from StatsCan

This project was completed as part of a Hackathon. The aim of the competition was to improve the experience of shoppers at Yorkdale Mall. Using association rules as the base algorithm, my team and I created a recommender system that suggests the next store that a shopper should visit based on his/her past shopping profile.
•	Dataset: 1.4 million real-world customer journeys as provided by Oxford Retail
•	Final Product: A fully functional recommender system that recommends “the next store to visit” based on users’ shopping history; repeat recommendations are not permitted.

jobs.title: Research Assistant
details: My research is focused on public participation at various spatial scales in light of the encroaching
convergence between social-technologies and algorithmically-regulated policies. The title of my
dissertation is "Coded Engagement:
Data
-Driven Participation in the Smart City", for which I am
actively undertaking an ambitious research protocol that includes the use and evaluation of a
variety of
data
science
techniques alongside many qualitative methods used in municipal
management.
McGill University
Exploring aspects of connectivity between citizens, communities, and city government, through spatial networks. Using analytical tools well-known to be useful in measuring community
participation and social capital for the real-world problems of making dumb cities "smart" that
allows for a panoptic view of their operations and population. Therefore, understanding coded
engagement is imperative so to establish practical paths towards "smart citizens living in a
censored city" instead of being forced into the corollary role of passive participation.
Social
Science
and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC)
Geothink examines the implications of increasing two-way exchanges of locational information between citizens and governments and the way in which technology shapes, and is shaped by,
this exchange. We couple government initiatives for open government and open access to
data
with citizens volunteered geographic contributions, and to spur innovation in operations and government-to-citizen-interactions.

jobs.title: Technical coordinator, Key Research & Development role
details: for the following projects:
Content analyses for e-learning systems
Measuring semantic similarity of text segments of Telecom e-learning content to build single source system. Distance oriented measures computed on semantic networks
NLP based algorithm for Semi automatic ontology population with multiple related named entities and object properties. Applying  norm-parameterized fuzzy DL for providence providing.

semi-automatic method for extracting information, specifically named entities and their relations, from texts and populating a domain ontology. While previous work has proposed solutions to extract named entities and populate them to classes an ontology, we are focused on the problem of accurately extracting and populating multiple relations between the same named entities and presenting them as distinct object properties between A-box individuals in an OWL-DL ontology.
Pilot 1 Innovatia  project. Semantic Queries for Telecom Call center
SPARQL queries for telecom call center use cases. Comparison of platforms for visual queries interfaces  and triple storers (KIM, TopBraid, Sesame)
Reasoning system for online lipids classification

Lipid molecules, presented as instance described as set of axioms "hasPart:FunctionalGroup" in n3 formalism is are  classified with reasoning system  (Pellet, OWLAPI, Fact++) with respect to Lipid Ontology (OWL2 ontology). Also includes: improving ontology design for better classification;  online evaluation system for predicted classes with respect to Lipid Map Structural Database, Wrapping the classifier in SADI web services
CALBS challenge participation (European Commission: 7th FRAMEWORK PROGRAMME)

The challenge is Creating a broadly-scoped and diversely annotated corpus (several 100,000 Medline abstracts on immunology annotated with about a dozen semantic groups) by automatically integrating the annotations from different named entity recognition and concept identification systems. The result of the integration process will be a silver standard corpus (SSC).

We deployed a text mining solution based on open source GATE framework. The basic implementation addressed the annotation of named entities and consists of two parts, namely preprocessing modules and a GATE annotation pipeline. Custom scripts were

developed for reformatting of annotations. The Java based preprocessing module was designed to break down corpus file to small chunks to be processed separately and to convert Gazetter list to a GATE compatible format. The GATE pipeline included two main steps, firstly a tokenizer for recognizing named entities in source text and connecting them with canonical names and semantic classes, and secondly a JAPE (Java Annotation Patterns Engine) rules for reformatting of annotations. To facilitate batch processing the GATE pipeline was wrapped in java and integrating with preprocessing module. The platform was used to annotate the CALBC corpus with chemical entities from ChEBI  and further annotated with Lipid named entities using a customized gazetteer list. In addition to corpus annotation we sought to map lipid named entities to canonical names assigned to classes in lipid ontology  to facilitate concept identification
Online Service Oriented Semantic Assistant architecture for Lipidomics Researchers. Joint project with Semantic Software Lab, Concordia University, Montreal

The Semantic Assistant Framework is a service-oriented architecture used to enhancing existing end-user clients, such Open Office Writter, with online Lipidomics text analysis capabilities provided as a set of web services. The Ontological NLP methodology links Lipid named entities occurred in a document opened on client side with existing Lipid ontologies on server side. The Ontology Axiom extractor annotates each named entity with canonical name, class name and related class axioms  providing annotation for documents on the client side.
Telecom Knowledge Management systems for Technical Product Support Contact Center. Joint project with Innovatia Inc, Bell Aliant

Ontology-centric knowledge discovery  custom solution for a telecommunications OEM technical contact center involving development of product-specific OWL-DL ontologies. Ontologies were populated from a wide variety of document formats with sentence-triples generated by a telecom-specific text mining pipeline that leverages document segmentation techniques
Semantic Assistant and Axioms extracting for telecom technical writers. Joint project with Innovatia Inc, Bell Aliant

To support the knowledge worker in the telecom vertical we introduce a new paradigm for knowledge sharing in which a client side application tags raw technical text with annotations, such as canonical name, class name or relevant class axioms, derived from the ontology - which has is delivered using web services framework. Our architecture includes the following core components: (i) Ontology; (ii) Ontological NLP pipeline; (iii) Ontology Axiom extractor; (vi) Semantic Assistant Framework
ML and Text Mining consulting on the following project:
Mutation Impact Extraction and Grounding. Joint project with Semantic Software Lab, Concordia University, Montreal

Rule-based approach for the extraction of mutation impacts on protein properties to populated to an OWL-DL Mutation Impact ontology facilitating complex query-answer for mutation impacts using  SPARQL. (Protein and mutation mentions are grounded to their respective UniProtKB IDs and protein properties, namely molecular functions and kinetic variables to concepts found in the Gene Ontology).
Tools in use: OWL API, Java, GATE\JAPE, Pellet, Fact++,   Protégé, Top Braid, KIM, Sesame, SPARQL, RDF, OWL, XML mySQL

Researcher Associate  (before October 2008 as a Post Doctoral Fellow)  -TAMALE (Text Analysis and MAchine LEarning) group, School of Information Technology and Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada

jobs.title: Invasive Species Technician
jobs.company: Ontario Federation of Anglers and Hunters
details: I worked as a consultant for the Ontario Federation of Anglers and Hunters, and my location was the Pinery Provincial Park.  Therefore I was providing consulting opportunities for the park to monitor and manage the invasive species within the park boundary and surrounding area.

I set up Invasive Species booths at Pinery's events to educate the public on invasive species.    I monitored invasive species through Environmental Impact Assessments using government forms to analyze effects of removing invasive plants and how it would affect native plants/animals, air, water as well as social issues such as the First Nations communities.

I completed site surveys by identifying European Buckthorn, and using GPS units to map tree locations and tagging plants for removal; tagged over 500 plants for removal in two months.  I communicated with local Conservation Authorities, Coastal Centre and cottage owners to discuss invasive species on their property and made recommendations based on observations.

I also did aquatic monitoring surveys to detect aquatic invasive species in the Pinery's water ways.  I researched potential invasive species and how to prevent them.  I can identify both invasive and native fish species in Southern Ontario.
I also did some Species At Risk research and site surveys using a GPS.  This allowed me to become more familiar with the different wildlife in the area.

When my contract was complete I completed a report on all my findings and provided it to both clients the OFAH and the Pinery Provincial Park.  The Pinery also used some of my articles in their yearly newspaper, and social media posts.

jobs.title: Independent GIS Consultant
details: I was hired as an external GIS consultant through the Department of Fisheries and Oceans.  I was selected based on my knowledge of fisheries biology and GIS skills.  It was here I first used invoices and Time Sheets to bill my client and manage my time and workload.  This widened my project management and time management skills.

This was my project so I was given a set of deliverables to acheive, I had to create a Terms of Reference, a list of milestones and a timeline to achieve these milestones.  I would work at my on pace remotely and send weekly progress reports and hours worked to the client.  When the project was done I complied all my
data
, deliverables and report and provided it directly to the client.  The client used the results for their own publication.

This project involved using a web-based GIS program to convert JPEG images into spatial maps of species distributions of fish families to compare the climate between the species distributions and selected areas to determine a fish's ability to adapt to North American climates and exported the
data
to excel spreadsheets; I created over 1000 maps in a 6 month period.

as a sessional Professor at the Mathematics Department at the Ryerson University. He also
served as the Head of Mathematics Department at the University General Requirements Unit
in UAEU and the Mathematics Team Leader at the Mathematics Department in ECAE. He
has also contributed as a director of the CEPA (Common Educational Proficiency
Assessment) at UAEU and a consultant for the national continuing assessment committee at
the ministry of education at Abu Dhabi.

This is another fun project where I built an interactive app that will display detailed demographic information (e.g., age, income, education, primary spoken language) about specific areas in Toronto, Mississauga, and Scarborough.
•	Dataset: Master dataset retrieved from StatsCan

This project was completed as part of a Hackathon. The aim of the competition was to improve the experience of shoppers at Yorkdale Mall. Using association rules as the base algorithm, my team and I created a recommender system that suggests the next store that a shopper should visit based on his/her past shopping profile.
•	Dataset: 1.4 million real-world customer journeys as provided by Oxford Retail

manipulation and transformation, mapping foot traffic using heatmaps, Association rules, design of a fully functional recommender system that recommends “the next store to visit” based on user shopping history. The algorithm is built such that it does not recommend a store that the shopper has already visited.
•	Final Product: A working recommender system

Wrote a book on financial analysis, trained 2 new managers, and re-wrote the company's employee training manuals. Monitored client portfolios daily, and assisted commercial managers with profitability analysis & sales development. Phoned over 30 clients each day and met regularly in person, discussing their operations, debt, and financial structure. Reviewed and approved proposals for capital and non-capital projects.

jobs.title: Assurance Associate & Business Analyst (co-op)
details: Audited, reviewed, and worked collaboratively to create the financial statements for over 15 consumer products, food & beverage, transportation, resource, education, and finance organizations.  Analyzed our client's industry and operations to determine risks, demand, and opportunities.
